byline.original: By Jane E. Brody; Jane E. Brody is the personal health columnist and a science writer for The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: SEVEN-YEAR-OLD JOSEPH'S ENTIRE face swells if he merely has a peanut in his mouth. Should he accidentally eat one he could die, the result, his mother says, of her having ''lived'' on peanut butter sandwiches when she was nursing him.
docs.snippet: LEAD: SEVEN-YEAR-OLD JOSEPH'S ENTIRE face swells if he merely has a peanut in his mouth. Should he accidentally eat one he could die, the result, his mother says, of her having ''lived'' on peanut butter sandwiches when she was nursing him.
